translated: Jātaka
Sattatinipāta
Kusavagga
. Kusajātaka

analyzed: idam te raṭṭham sa dhanam sa yogga
translated: “This kingdom of yours is prosperous, with good allies,
With its own people, with all desires fulfilled;
Rule this kingdom, dear mother,
I will go where my beloved Pabhāvatī is.”
“With a mind of goodwill take the great wealth,
By day and night and at the time of dawn;
Quickly take Kusāvatī, Kusā,
I wish to leave, staying here is unpleasant.”
“I will not go from here to Kusāvatī,
I am attracted by the beauty of Pabhāvatī;
I delight in the dwelling of Maddarājā,
Having abandoned your kingdom, I delight in seeing you.
Attracted by the beauty of Pabhāvatī,
I wander the earth in a state of confusion;

analyzed: disam na jānāmi kutas ahi āgataḥ
translated: I do not know the direction from which I have come,
In this I am intoxicated by the doe-eyed one.
Wearing golden garments,

analyzed: jātarūpa su mekhale  sussoṇi tava kāmāḥ hi
translated: with golden ornaments,🔽O Sussoni, I am not intoxicated by the kingdom,
but by your love.”
“It is a great gain for him,
who desires one who does not desire him;
“You desire the king, O Queen,
but he does not desire you.”

original: “Akāmaṁ vā sakāmaṁ vā,🔽yo naro labhate piyaṁ;
analyzed: akāmam vā sa kāmam vā  yaḥ naraḥ labhate piya
translated: “Whether one desires it or not,🔽if a man obtains what is dear to him,
there is praise in that gain,

analyzed: alābhaḥ tattha pāpako  pāsāṇa sāram khaṇasi  kaṇikārassa dārunā
translated: but the non-gain is bad.”🔽“You are cutting stone with the wood of a kaṇikāra tree,
you are trying to stop the wind with a net,
if you desire one who does not desire you.”
“Surely a stone is placed in your heart,
O you of soft appearance,

analyzed: yā u te sātam na vindāmi
translated: since I do not find satisfaction in you,

analyzed: tiras janapada āgataḥ  yadā mam bhakuṭim katvā
translated: having come from a distant country.🔽When the King’s daughter, with a frown,
looks at me,
then I am Āḷāra,

analyzed: raññaḥ mad dassa antepure  yadā umhayamānā ma
translated: in the King’s city of Madhurā.🔽When the King’s daughter, with a smile,
looks at me,
then I am Nāḷāgiri,
then I am King Kusa.”

analyzed: sace hi vacanam sat ca  nemittānam bhavissati
translated: “If the words of the augurs are true,

analyzed: na iva me tvam patī assa
translated: then you will not be my husband,
may they cut you into seven pieces.”
“If the words of the augurs are true,
whether of you or of me,
you will not have a husband,
another than Sīhasūra, Kusa.”
“I’ll break your neck,
having fallen, crooked one, to Kusāvatī,
If, you with the nose of a nāga,
Pabhāvatī looks at me.
I’ll break your neck,
having fallen, crooked one, to Kusāvatī,
If, you with the nose of a nāga,
Pabhāvatī speaks to me.
I’ll break your neck,
having fallen, crooked one, to Kusāvatī,
If, you with the nose of a nāga,
Pabhāvatī thinks of me.
I’ll break your neck,
having fallen, crooked one, to Kusāvatī,
If, you with the nose of a nāga,
Pabhāvatī remembers me.
I’ll break your neck,
having fallen, crooked one, to Kusāvatī,
If, you with the nose of a nāga,
you touch me with your hands.”

analyzed: na hi nūna ayam rāja puttī
translated: “Surely this is not a princess,
who finds pleasure in a reed.
You should support her, Āḷavaka,
without wages.”

analyzed: na hi nūna ayam sā khujjā
translated: “Surely this is not a crooked one,
who gets her tongue cut off.
With a well-sharpened sword,
she speaks so badly.”
“Don’t be carried away by her beauty,
by her height, Pabhāvatī,
Having called him “Great Vehicle,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Great Wealth,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Great Strength,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Great Country,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Great King,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;🔽Having called him “Lion’s Roar,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Bull’s Roar,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Drop’s Roar,”
do what is lovely and dear.
Do not let him be carried away by form,
by height, by splendor;
Having called him “Sweet Roar,”
Do what is pleasing to the beautiful one.
Do not be deceived by her beauty,
by her height, the radiant one;
Having called her ‘sweet-voiced’,
do what is pleasing to the beautiful one.
Do not be deceived by her beauty,
by her height, the radiant one;
Having called her ‘hundred-eyed’,
do what is pleasing to the beautiful one.
Do not be deceived by her beauty,
by her height, the radiant one;
Having called her ‘noble’,
do what is pleasing to the beautiful one.
Do not be deceived by her beauty,
by her height, the radiant one;
Having called her ‘Kusārā’,
do what is pleasing to the beautiful one.”
“These elephants are ready,
all stand with their trunks held out;
Before they break down the ramparts,
bring out this radiant one.”

analyzed: satta bile karitvāna  aham etam pabhāvati
translated: “Having made seven pits,
I will give this radiant one (to the princes),
those who have come here to kill me.”
“The princess has come out,
the one dressed in silk,
with eyes full of tears,
attended by a group of female slaves.”
“Surely that face, frequented by the wicked,
looked at by the teeth and the lips,
The beautiful, the lovely, the stainless, the pure,
Will dwell in the forest, abandoned by the Khattiyas.

original: Te nūna me asite vellitagge,🔽Kese mudū candanasāralitte;
analyzed: te nūna me asite velli tagge  kese mudū candana sāra litte
translated: They will surely drag my hair, which is uncombed,🔽My soft hair, anointed with the essence of sandalwood,
In the midst of a tangled mass of grass and reeds,
With their feet, the vultures.

analyzed: tā nūna me tamba nakhā su lomā
translated: They will surely drag my arms, which are soft,
Anointed with the essence of sandalwood,
Cut off in the forest, abandoned by the Khattiyas,
The dhaṅka bird will go wherever it wishes.
They will surely hang my neck, which is like a palm fruit,
Anointed with Kāsi sandalwood,
On the branches, the jackal will hang,
Like a young son, the offspring of a doe.🔽They will surely drag the large, well-shaped

original: Taṁ nūna soṇiṁ puthulaṁ sukoṭṭitaṁ,🔽Nisevitaṁ kañcanamekhalāhi;
analyzed: tam nūna soṇim puthulam su koṭṭita  nisevitam kañcana mekhalā hi
translated: Anointed with golden bracelets,
The cut off cloth in the forest, by the Khattiyas,
The flock of jackals.
The red dhaṅkas, jackals,
and whatever other carnivores there are,
Will surely become ageless
by devouring Pabhāvatī.🔽If the far-traveling Khattiyas
have carried off the flesh,
“After you have asked for the bones,
burn them on the road.
“After you have had the fields prepared,
sow them with black mustard seed.
When they are in flower,
at the end of the cold winter,
you must send me word, mother,
that Pabhāvatī is such and such.”
“The mother of the king’s daughter,
a noble lady, beautiful as a goddess,
saw the sword and the empty bier,
in the king’s palace at Maddakucchi.
“With this sword, no doubt,
the slender-waisted, lovely girl,
after killing the king’s daughter,
will show her to the nobles.
She did not do what I said,
to me who wished her well, my child.
Now, covered in blood,
you are going to Yama’s place.
Thus a man comes to ruin

analyzed: pāpiyañca nigacchati  yaḥ veḥ hitānam vacana
translated: and goes to a bad rebirth,🔽if he does not do what is said
by one who sees what is good for him.

analyzed: sace ca ajja dhāresi  kumāram cārudassana
translated: But if today you were to take🔽the prince, so lovely to behold,

analyzed: kusena jātam khattiya  suvaṇṇa maṇi mekhala
translated: born of a golden-hued noble lady,🔽with a golden girdle and jewels,
honoured by the assembly of relatives,
you would not go to Yama’s abode.
Where the drum resounds,
And the elephant bellows.
In a family of nobles, good lady,
what is more pleasant than that?”
“The horse neighs at the gate,
and the prince cries out.
In a family of nobles, good lady,
what is more pleasant than that?”
“With peacocks and geese calling out,
and cuckoos cooing,
in a family of nobles, good lady,
what is more pleasant than that?”
“Where is that destroyer of enemies,
that destroyer of other countries?
That Kusā, who has sixteen insights,
who will free us from suffering.”
“Right here is that destroyer of enemies,
that destroyer of other countries.
That Kusā, who has sixteen insights,

original: yo te sabbe vadhissati”.🔽“Ummattikā nu bhaṇasi,
analyzed: yaḥ te sabbe vadhissati  ummattikā nu bhaṇasi
translated: who will kill you all.”🔽“Are you mad?
You are blind and foolish and prattle on.
If Kusā has come here,
how would we not know it?”
“That man from Āḷāra,
in the women’s quarters of the prince,
having firmly fastened the bolt,
is washing a pot, bent over.”
“You are a braid-wearer, a Caṇdāla woman,
a slanderer, stinking of sex.
How is it that you, born in a low family,
you should be my slave, lustful one.”
“I am not a braid-wearer or a caṇḍālī,
nor am I a woman with a bad smell;
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yaḥ brāhmaṇa sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?”🔽“One who always feeds
twenty-thousand brāhmaṇas,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yassa nāga sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?🔽One who always has
twenty-thousand elephants yoked,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yassa assa sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?🔽One who always has
twenty-thousand horses yoked,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yassa ratha sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?🔽One who always has
twenty-thousand chariots yoked,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yassa usabha sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?🔽One who always has
twenty-thousand bulls yoked,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,

analyzed: tvam nu dāsa iti maññasi  yassa dhenu sahassāni
translated: do you think I am a slave?🔽One who always has
twenty-thousand cows milking,
I am the son of Okkāka, reverend Sir,
do you think I am a slave?”
“Indeed, foolish woman, you have done wrong,
the powerful Khattiya;
The frog-coloured nāga,
did not recognize you, who have come here.”

analyzed: aparādham mahā rāja  tvam naḥ khama rathesabha
translated: “Great king, you must forgive us,🔽you who are the equal of Indra,
because we did not recognize you,
who came here in disguise.”
“It is not right for one like me,
who is a follower of Āḷāra,
You should be appeased,
there is no fault in you, god.”

analyzed: gaccha bāle khamāpehi  kusa rājam mahabbala
translated: “Go, fool, and ask for forgiveness,🔽the powerful King Kusa;
King Kusa has been asked for forgiveness,
he will give you your life.”
“Having heard her father’s words,
Devavaṇṇī, of great beauty,
bowed her head to the feet
of the powerful King Kusa.”
“The pleasures of the Tāvatiṃsa gods,
without you, god, are not enjoyable;
I bow my head to your feet,
do not be angry with me, Indra’s equal.
I confess everything to you,
great king, listen to me;
I will not do anything displeasing to you,
ever again.

original: vacanaṁ me na kāhasi;🔽Idāni maṁ tāto hantvā,
analyzed: vacanam me na kā ahasi 🔽idāni mam tātaḥ hantvā
translated: If you do not do what I ask,🔽even though I beg you in this way;🔽Then my father will kill me, and I will die,
will be destroyed by the Khattiyas.”
“If you ask me in this way,
why should I not do what you say?
I am confused, my dear,
do not be afraid, Pabhāvatī.
I admit everything to you,

original: rājaputti suṇohi me;🔽Na cāpi appiyaṁ tuyhaṁ,
analyzed: rājaputti suṇohi me  na ca api appiyam
translated: listen to me, daughter of a king;🔽I will not do anything unpleasant to you
again.
For your sake, Sussondi,
I endured great suffering;
Having killed many of the Maddas,
I will take you away, Pabhāvatī.”
“Let them yoke the horses to the chariot,
of various colors, well-trained;
Then you will see my speed,
as I go out to fight.”
“They looked on there,
in the king’s presence in the city of the Maddas;
As if roaring like a lion,
shaking his double arms.
Having mounted the elephant’s back,🔽and placed Pabhāvatī on it,
having entered the battle,
Kusa let out a lion’s roar.
Having heard his roar,
the deer that were following the lion,
the Khattiyas fled,
terrified by the sound of Kusa.
The elephant riders, the leaders,
The charioteers and the infantry,
They cut each other down,
Terrified by the sound of the grass.

analyzed: tasmin  passitvā haṭṭha mānasaḥ  kusassa raññaḥ devindo
translated: In that battle, the king of the gods,🔽Seeing the joy in the king’s mind,
Gave to King Kusā the jewel Verocana.

original: So taṁ vijitvā saṅgāmaṁ,🔽laddhā verocanaṁ maṇiṁ;
analyzed: saḥ u tam vijitvā saṅgāma  laddhā verocanam maṇi
translated: Having won that battle,🔽And having obtained the jewel Verocana,
The king, riding on an elephant,
Returned to the city.🔽Having captured them alive,
And having bound the seven nobles,
He brought them to his father-in-law,
saying: “These are your seven sons-in-law, great king.”
“All of them have come under your control,
your enemies have been defeated;
Do as you wish with them,
release them or kill them.”
“These are your seven sons-in-law,
they are not my sons-in-law;
You are our great king,
release them or kill them.”
“These are your seven daughters,
beautiful like the daughters of the gods;
Give them to each of them,

analyzed: hontu jāmātaraḥ tava  amhākam ca iva tāsam ca
translated: let them be your sons-in-law.”🔽“You are the lord of us all,
of them and of us;
You are our great king,
Give them what they want.”

original: Ekamekassa ekekaṁ,🔽adā sīhassaro kuso;🔽Khattiyānaṁ tadā tesaṁ,
analyzed: ekam ekassa eka eka  adāḥ sīhassaro kuso  khattiyānam tadā
translated: To each of them he gave,
Kusāvatī, the daughter of King Madhu.
They were satisfied with that gain,
and the Kusāvatī people were content;
They drank the water of the kingdom,
the seven nobles for a while.
And taking the Pārebhāsa jewel,
the beautiful Verocana gem;
King Kusa, of great strength,
went to Kusāvatī.
As they were riding in the same chariot,
entering Kusāvatī;
Although they were of the same colour and form,
they did not recognise each other.
The mother met with her son,
and both the victorious lords;
They were united then,
and lived on the prosperous earth.🔽The Kusajātaka is the first.
